-Consistent and regular teacher feedback on academic work and real academic grades
-Regular group check-ins with a teacher advisor for social and emotional connection
-Support for technology usage for students and families
-A device for all students and wifi where needed

We know you might be wondering what you'll get asked if a contact tracer calls you. You can find the kinds of information a contact tracer will ask for in the graphic below.

A contact tracer will NEVER ask for your social security number, immigration status, credit card, bank account or billing information. If anyone calls you requesting this information, hang up. They are not part of local or state contact tracing efforts.

Visit our contact tracing website to learn more about this important public health strategy to slow the spread of COVID-19: healthoregon.org/contacttracing

Our Distance Learning Spotlight shines on the Skyles family from Hollydale Elementary School! They shared with us the successes and challenges of Distance Learning! #InThisTogether
What do you like best about Distance Learning?
Our family enjoys the flexible schedule of Distance Learning and the ability for our children to go at their own pace. As parents we also enjoy the ability to get to sit down and work through problems with them and we like having the kids share with us what they are working on throughout the day. The girls frequently mention how much they enjoy the live google classroom meets.
What have you found to be challenging?
In the beginning it was challenging to navigate the different programs and applications. The girls feel like they are missing out on the social interaction of in building school.
Do you have advice for other families:
If you feel like you are having challenges, reach out for assistance; teachers and staff are there to help! Parents give yourself grace and know there will be mistakes, this is something that has never been done before.

Our Distance Learning Spotlight shines on the Smalley family from Hollydale Elementary School! They shared with us the successes and challenges of Distance Learning! #InThisTogether
What do you like best about Distance Learning?
We really enjoy the art projects we have done as a family. The way we can do at our own pace. The support from our teachers has been wonderful.
What have you found to be challenging?
The most challenging is that we aren’t teachers. We don’t all have the patience or the skill level to teach our kiddos. It has made us much more grateful for the teachers at the school.
Advice for other families:
My advice is that you can’t do everything. Some days math in our house looks like baking cookies. PE looks like jumping on the trampoline. We will all get through this some way or another. Hang in there!

Our Distance Learning Spotlight shines on the Schulz Family from East Orient Elementary School! They shared with us the successes and challenges of Distance Learning! #InThisTogether
What do you like best about Distance Learning?
The peace of mind it provides by knowing our student and others are able to stay home, be socially distant, and remain healthy. Academically we love our bi-weekly class meetings via Google Meet.
What have you found to be challenging?
Balancing the demands of a full-time work schedule while helping and making sure our student stays on track. I’m very grateful to be able to work remotely but it definitely takes multi-tasking to a new level.
Advice for other families:
Do your best to keep to a schedule and routine. We start, take breaks, and end the day regularly at the same time. On Fridays, if all the work is turned in, our student gets to take the rest of the day off after our lunch break for “Friday Fun.” It has worked as a great incentive!

The peace of mind it provides by knowing our student and others are able to stay home, be socially distant, and remain healthy. Academically we love our bi-weekly class meetings via Google Meet.
What have you found to be challenging?
Balancing the demands of a full-time work schedule while helping and making sure our student stays on track. I’m very grateful to be able to work remotely but it definitely takes multi-tasking to a new level.
Advice for other families:
Do your best to keep to a schedule and routine. We start, take breaks, and end the day regularly at the same time. On Fridays, if all the work is turned in, our student gets to take the rest of the day off after our lunch break for “Friday Fun.” It has worked as a great incentive!

Our Distance Learning Spotlight shines on the Lackner/Gonzales Family from West Gresham Elementary School! McKenna’s mom Kate shared with us the successes and challenges of Distance Learning! #InThisTogether
What do you like best about Distance Learning?
The various websites and resources available that can be used for education makes distance learning interesting and fun. It’s not a “one size fits all” and can be tailored to our household’s schedule.
What have you found to be challenging?
Motivation. Being the “only” student at the house can be challenging to keep a Kindergartener motivated and focused.
Advice for other families:
Set short interval study times. At the Kindergarten grade level, the focus can be short and sometimes they need a little more motivation. Some days we get more work completed than others and that is okay!

shared_text:
Highland Elementary School
April 10 at 8:07 PM ·

Oh Highland Community! Do we ever have great news to share!

Our Free Food Market was a HUGE success today!

We supplied food for 220 families today! 220!

Last week we ran out of food, and our community wasn’t having that! 😉 We had donations from many beautiful people today including a MASSIVE donation from our faith-based partner, Mountainview Christian Church. They put out a call to their congregation, and they showed up in large numbers with big hearts, giving hands, and donations galore! We served 50 MORE families than last week and we DID NOT run out of food!

Principal Sewell and her youngest son, Grafton, spent three hours converting our lobby into a storage pantry so that we are better organized and prepared for future Free Food Market dates.

We can’t say “thank you” enough to Mountainview Christian Church, all the good, giving people, the volunteers that make this Market happen, and the leadership of Ms. Betty, Ms. Dani, and Ms. Sandra.

#freefoodmarket
#goodfriday
#bestfaithbasedpartnerever
#weareallinthistogether
#Attitudeofgraditude
#bestcommunityever
